holdings.text: The Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 did not terminate the petitioners' subsisting mining lease; instead, Section 10 deemed it to continue as a lease from the State Government substituting the original lessor, on the same terms, entitling petitioners to retain possession.

anchor.surface_text: As the lease in favour of the petitioners was subsisting on the date of vesting of the Ladi Estate, the lease, with effect from the date of vesting, became statutorily a lease granted by the State Government to the petitioners for the remainder of the term of that lease and the petitioners became entitled to retain possession of the lease-hold property. There can be no manner of doubt that the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 could not have put an end to the title of the petitioners. The only effect of that Act was this, that instead of being lessees under Kumar Amardeyal Singh and his successors, the petitioners became lessees directly under Government on the same terms and conditions on which the original lease had been granted to their predecessor in-interest by Kumar Amardeyal Singh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of Sec.10: 'deemed to have been leased by the State Government'; reaffirmed by prior SC decision in Bihar Mines Ltd. v. Union of India.

holdings.text: The Controller of Mining Leases' order dated 28 September 1959 modifying and terminating the petitioners' lease was invalid and of no legal effect.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Patna High Court has held that the order of the Controller of Mining Leases was invalid and of no legal effect whatsoever. This finding has been confirmed by this Court in the Bihar Mines Ltd. v. Union of India where it has been held that it is not the effect of Sec. 10 of Bihar Land Reforms Act that a subsisting lease continues under the Government with the Government substituted as the lessor in place of the original lessor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows prior Patna HC and SC holdings; Sec.10 creates new statutory lease not subject to that modification.

holdings.text: Entries in Register D under Land Registration Act are prima facie evidence of proprietorship but not conclusive proof of title to grant mining lease, as mutation proceedings are fiscal inquiries not determining proprietary rights.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn to Sec. 4 of the Land Registration Act, 1876 which though a Bengal Act 18 of 1876 is, the Act applicable to Bihar. Sec. 4 of that Act describes the various registers which the Collector, of every district has to prepare and maintain... the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council held that proceedings for the mutation of names are not judicial proceedings in which title to and proprietary rights in immovable property can be determined.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory purpose of registers (fiscal); follows Privy Council (Nirman Singh) and SC (Marudeswarar Temple) precedents on revenue entries not conclusive.

holdings.text: No estoppel arises against a lessee from any admission made by the lessor (Government) after the lease has been granted to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: No estoppel as against a lessee can arise from any admission made by the lessor after the lease has been granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle of estoppel in leases; post-grant admission does not bind subsequent lessee.

holdings.text: Writ proceedings under Art.226 are not appropriate to decide disputed title questions, declare title, or order restoration of possession against a party in actual possession raising a bona fide title challenge; parties should file civil suit.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the appellant had actually been put into possession of the land in respect of which Bihar Government gave the appellant a mining lease... proceedings by way of a writ were not appropriate in a case where the decision of the Court would amount to a decree declaring a partys title and ordering restoration of possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows SC precedent in Sohan Lal v. Union of India; distinguishes Mohd. Hanif (no possession dispute there); balances possession and title adjudication.

holdings.text: Mohd. Hanif v. State of Assam is distinguishable as it involved executive interference with petitioner's possession, unlike here where appellant is in possession and title disputed.

anchor.surface_text: Mohd. Hanif filed an application in the Assam High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution of India... That was clearly a case of executive interference with the possession of the petitioner Mohd. Hanif.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual distinction: possession status and nature of interference.

holdings.text: Petitioners failed to prove conclusive title; prima facie case insufficient to displace possessor (appellant) via writ; High Court erred in quashing leases.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the view that we have taken of this case we cannot uphold the decision of the Patna High Court... The petitioners have failed to produce any clear, conclusive and unimpeachable documentary evidence in support of their contention that Kumar Amardeyal Singh was proprietor who could have granted such a lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence evaluation: Register D prima facie only; no conclusive proof; writ limits.

holdings.text: Judgment does not determine petitioners' title question; appeal allowed, Patna High Court judgment set aside; parties bear own costs.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we set aside the judgment and order dated 17 September 1971 of the Patna High Court and allow the appeal. In the peculiar facts and circumstances of this case we direct that the parties should bear their own respective costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings; procedural outcome; clarifies non-decision on title.

h1 states the effect of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 on the petitioners' mining lease (did not terminate but continued under Section 10 as lease from State), directly answering i2 on the Act's effect on petitioners' rights and title.

anchor.surface_text: As the lease in favour of the petitioners was subsisting on the date of vesting of the Ladi Estate, the lease, with effect from the date of vesting, became statutorily a lease granted by the State Government to the petitioners for the remainder of the term of that lease and the petitioners became entitled to retain possession of the lease-hold property. There can be no manner of doubt that the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 could not have put an end to the title of the petitioners. The only effect of that Act was this, that instead of being lessees under Kumar Amardeyal Singh and his successors, the petitioners became lessees directly under Government on the same terms and conditions on which the original lease had been granted to their predecessor in-interest by Kumar Amardeyal Singh.

Accordingly, we set aside the judgment and order dated 17 September 1971 of the Patna High Court and allow the appeal. In the peculiar facts and circumstances of this case we direct that the parties should bear their own respective companyts

edges.explanation: Holding that Controller's terminating order invalid directly addresses issue of whether Controller could terminate lease

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Patna High Court has held that the order of the Controller of Mining Leases was invalid and of no legal effect whatsoever. This finding has been confirmed by this Court in the Bihar Mines Ltd. v. Union of India where it has been held that it is not the effect of Sec. 10 of Bihar Land Reforms Act that a subsisting lease continues under the Government with the Government substituted as the lessor in place of the original lessor.

Accordingly, we set aside the judgment and order dated 17 September 1971 of the Patna High Court and allow the appeal. In the peculiar facts and circumstances of this case we direct that the parties should bear their own respective companyts

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn to Sec. 4 of the Land Registration Act, 1876 which though a Bengal Act 18 of 1876 is, the Act applicable to Bihar. Sec. 4 of that Act describes the various registers which the Collector, of every district has to prepare and maintain... the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council held that proceedings for the mutation of names are not judicial proceedings in which title to and proprietary rights in immovable property can be determined.

Accordingly, we set aside the judgment and order dated 17 September 1971 of the Patna High Court and allow the appeal. In the peculiar facts and circumstances of this case we direct that the parties should bear their own respective companyts

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the view that we have taken of this case we cannot uphold the decision of the Patna High Court... The petitioners have failed to produce any clear, conclusive and unimpeachable documentary evidence in support of their contention that Kumar Amardeyal Singh was proprietor who could have granted such a lease.

Accordingly, we set aside the judgment and order dated 17 September 1971 of the Patna High Court and allow the appeal. In the peculiar facts and circumstances of this case we direct that the parties should bear their own respective companyts
